content.description:
Some interesting moves. 

  Up the big right-facing inside corner / dihedral on the right side of the 20-ft pillar, move left to exit its top, then trend a bit right on slab above. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Below right side of 20-ft-high rectangular pillar on the left end of the Scheyichbi cliff. 

  - - > See on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description:
Good practice of thoughtful moves on slab footholds without positive handholds, if you like that sort of thing. 

  Start up center of low boulder 5-6 ft high, then up the left-facing corner. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is standard rack.
content.location:
Below left-facing corner along left edge of the main face. 

  - - > See on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description:
Interesting moves all the way.

 Up the crack. Crux is about ten feet up. . (If on top-rope and can't get the crux move, consider "yarding" up past it, then enjoying the rest of this great climb).

 . . . (Some guidebooks or apps call this route "Undercling Layback").

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector.

 Protection for Trad leading is standard rack with a focus on small cams for the first ~20ft (black and blue totem). #1 and 0.5 Camalots are useful higher where the climbing eases.
content.location:
The obvious vertical crack in left center of the main wall. 

  - - > See on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description:
Interesting moves. 

  Up to the right-facing flake, then up the flake, and on to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is standard rack.
content.location:
On the main wall about fifteen feet right from the vertical finger crack, below right-facing flake a few inches deep. 

  - - > See on this Photo

content.description:
Lots of fun moves. 

  Start up left side of low boulder 5-6 ft high, then up wide gully 6-10 left from left-facing corner.  

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.

content.description:
Up the face or arete which forms the right side of the big inside corner / dihedral on the right side of the pillar, then the face above. Wander more left or more right as desired. 

  Variation: No wandering: Start and stay directly on the arete; then finish up through center of steeper section of slab above. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.

content.description:
Thoughtful moves w Delicate footwork.  

  Mount the arete without using the low block to its right. Up the arete using holds on both sides. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see Description of this Scheyichbi sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.

Right (SW) corner of main face of obvious pillar 20-25 feet high and 7 feet wide on Left (SW) end of this Scheyichbi sector

content.description:
Thoughtful sequence with few holds. 

  Get onto the face without stepping on the small blocks to its left. Up the left side of face - (left arete is on). 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Up over / around left side of the small roof, up a bit farther, then right and up. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.

content.description:
About 40 feet high with a variety of rock features -- especially the finger crack. 

  Three minutes off main trail. 

  Main wall faces SouthWest, left end faces NorthWest. 

  Top-Rope: To get access to the top of the cliff, can scramble up around the left side. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern in this sector. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . (sometimes spelled Sheyichbi).
